titleStmt.title: Letter, James L. Dodds in Camp Meade, Md., to Ellen Smith, in Jackson, Tenn.,1918 Jan. 4

publicationStmt.publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries Digital Initiatives

availability.p: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.

bibl.title: Letter, James L. Dodds in Camp Meade, Md., to Ellen Smith, in Jackson, Tenn.,1918 Jan. 4

projectDesc.p: Machine-readable transcription created for the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections.

editorialDecl.p: Errors in transcription of the printed text not controlled.
Editorial tags limited to gap and unclear.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

revisionDesc.change: Approximate date of original transcription and transcriber.
Migrating from P4 to validated TEI P5.

div.p: I received your letter this a.m. and was real glad to here from you I dont know very murch to write but I will see how well I can do.

Well I guess you are not cooking so murch now as Christmas is over I have had my shair of working in the kitchen but havent had any children to take care of I thank I could do that too for I have learned to do most ever thing around the house. You should see me pushing a broom I am the best in town But I dont like to at all.

I thank the dances are about a thing of the past in Jaxon the last 2 or 3 I was at before I left I dident a good time at all I dont know what is the matter unless the crowd has changed so murch from what it was 4 or 5 years ago.
I guess it did seem good to see Mr and Mrs Chandler back in Jaxon. I would like to see them Myself but there is nothing doing But if I am in this Country when spring comes I am going to come home
for a few days or just as many days as they will let me stay. About the first of April is the time I am thanking about coming home.
Well I say you wouldent miss any thing of entrest if you do miss the picture I sure wish I could see a show of some kind they have shows here at the Y.M.C.A. but I cant go I am under quaranteen Now
I am slipping this letter out or I am going to try to I dont know if I will get it out or not I know Esther is a happy girl now her husban has got there at last I dont blame her at all.
I say Santee was good to you I wouldent know what to do with so many presents. I dident get a thing but a little bundle from Red Cross had a checker board a pencil and sack of tobacco

Mother sent me a Christmas box with some thing to eat but she put some stuff in a fruit jar and the jar broke and liked to have ruined the hole thing I was some mad about it but that dident do any good

It looked so good to and I couldent eat it and was just starving for some thing like this Well I dont know any thing else to write So I will close write me real soon and tell me all the news As ever the same
